Honestly, I've had the opposite experience. I found learning the game and grinding up to 30 to be immensely frustrating. I made stupid mistakes, knew I was making stupid mistakes, and was having my teammates take it out of my hide rather than helping in the vast majority of cases. It seemed like I was playing with as many smurfs as other newbies, and they would just take over games and abuse the other players. I also had no sense of value for how to manage my IP, the relative importance of building a champion pool vs. runes, and so on and felt leagues behind. This isn't particularly surprising, and I don't really blame Riot for much of it. While they could improve the onboarding experience for new players it is an area they are aware of and working on. It is a difficult problem. League is a very mechanically complex game, with lots of moving parts, and enjoyment will naturally increase along with mastery.

As a result, I now enjoy League a great deal more. I've been able to gather people I enjoy playing with on my friends list, started climbing the ranked ladder, and start learning multiple roles. I started as a support main simply because it was the role that nobody else wanted, and that was the only way I could reliably get practice in a single role. I've now gotten to the point where I can pick up jungle and top, and am now working on mid/adc. There's a huge range of champions and playstyles to explore. I just got Yasuo as my free champ and tried him out in a custom vs. bots. I'm terrible with him, but had a blast. I'm going to train up on him incase I ever need to fill as an AD mid. The future is bright.
League is love, League is life.
There is a lot of magic that you get at the start, its so great. You try out your first few champions and actually have fun leveling up. That magic just starts going away after awhile.

You are thinking "A tanky Assassin that is Braum" from what it sounds like, while i wrote, "An Assassin that is tanky as Braum" meaning that an Assassin (which are not a tanky class) still being Tanky enough to survive 3 turret shots, as if they were playing as a tanky champion, for example a Braum (which is a tanky Champ that can survive several turret shots since that is pretty much their  job as a tank).  It is poor perception, with lack of in-depth description, but enough information was provided to  lead one to a conclusion since it contains enough context. In this case, to reach the conclusion that Braum is not the one  solo diving and getting a triple kill, but instead a champion that belongs to the  Assassin class. Had i capitalized the "A" in Assassin, it might have helped perceive things a little different. Furthermore, i could have exagerated a bit more to get the point across with "tankier than Braum or Garen" instead of "tanky as Braum or Garen" to help facilitate the message that was trying to come across.

But if the  perception is different, the conclusion and context reached is different.

So one more time, "A Tanky Assassin tanky as Braum", which is not the same as an Assassin Braum Triple Killing while tower-diving. TWO different things.

I've always had a simple rule with myself. Have fun. I don't play ranked (ranked still doesn't matter in my eyes, its all a game isn't it?) and I've always had the mentality that if you're playing a game and not having fun then you should stop playing that game. I have fun even when my team loses because either way, I'm playing a furry little dinosaur that turns into a big furry dinosaur, or a dude who really _really_ knows his stuff about air currents ( {{champion:157}} ). I have fun because I enjoy the gameplay of the game, I enjoy the art style and I enjoy the characters. I still try my hardest, but I don't get stressed if my hardest isn't enough.
10/10 would agree again.
